issue.title: Switched build system to CMake.
issue.body:
## Build Instructions

To build on UNIX-y systems: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -GNinja .. && ninja`

To build on Windows: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -G "Ninja" .. && ninja"` in the VS Developer console. Alternatively, just running `cmake ..` will generate build files for Visual Studio.

To build shared libraries: `cmake -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -GNinja ..`
To use (or not use) OpenSSL, pass `-DUSE_OPENSSL={ON|OFF}`
To disable (for example) all SPHINCS variants, pass `-DENABLE_SIG_SPHINCS=OFF`

To run all the tests, invoke `ninja run_tests`
To build documentation, invoke `ninja gen_docs`

comment.body: All tests pass on my Raspberry Pi running Raspbian.

issue.title: Switched build system to CMake.
issue.body:
## Build Instructions

To build on UNIX-y systems: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -GNinja .. && ninja`

To build on Windows: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -G "Ninja" .. && ninja"` in the VS Developer console. Alternatively, just running `cmake ..` will generate build files for Visual Studio.

To build shared libraries: `cmake -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -GNinja ..`
To use (or not use) OpenSSL, pass `-DUSE_OPENSSL={ON|OFF}`
To disable (for example) all SPHINCS variants, pass `-DENABLE_SIG_SPHINCS=OFF`

To run all the tests, invoke `ninja run_tests`
To build documentation, invoke `ninja gen_docs`

comment.body:
Hmm - unsure whether this has to do with my 'autoconf-infested' machine, but after doing pull, checkout cmake and following your README, my Ubuntu VM spat out myriads of warnings (while building) and ultimately failed with missing symbols (dso_dlfcn.c:(.text+0x11): undefined reference to `dlopen', etc.). I'll repeat this later on a 'clean' image. In any case, if you know of "migration headaches" for people with a running/'old' build-env/Makefiles, maybe a short 'clean-your-present-installation-to-get-cmake-to-work' HOWTO may be good? Could be as simple as `rm -rf liboqs; git clone ....` (if that's the recommendation). You may also want to update links referred-to in the new README (e.g., https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Building seems outdated).

One final suggestion, if I may: Would it be sensible to make building both static and dynamic libs the default? Some "downstream apps" work best when built shared...

comment.body:
The build warnings are to be expected, and we'll fix them in the coming days.

@vsoftco the macOS build fails in that same way on CircleCI, but it does not fail on my Mac. I suspect it has to do with the CPU features detection. If you pass in `-DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug` it should work fine, which is what I did for the CI scripts.

issue.title: Switched build system to CMake.
issue.body:
## Build Instructions

To build on UNIX-y systems: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -GNinja .. && ninja`

To build on Windows: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -G "Ninja" .. && ninja"` in the VS Developer console. Alternatively, just running `cmake ..` will generate build files for Visual Studio.

To build shared libraries: `cmake -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -GNinja ..`
To use (or not use) OpenSSL, pass `-DUSE_OPENSSL={ON|OFF}`
To disable (for example) all SPHINCS variants, pass `-DENABLE_SIG_SPHINCS=OFF`

To run all the tests, invoke `ninja run_tests`
To build documentation, invoke `ninja gen_docs`

comment.body:
I tested the build my Windows 10 x64 machine, both on Windows and in the Linux subsystem (WSL Ubuntu 18.04)

- Windows: I used the VS2019 command console to build the documented ninja cmake; worked.
- Linux: I tested both the ninja and non-ninja (`cmake ..`) builds. Both got a bunch of warnings, but compiled correctly. @xvzcf, you only document how to run the tests with ninja. Will there be a way to run them without it (`make tests` doesn’t do anything anymore)? I ran them manually calling `python3 -m pytest` and they passed. With ninja, I had to remove the `--numprocesses=auto` option to start the tests; they passed.

comment.body:
@christianpaquin you can run the tests without ninja, you just have to run the command [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/cmake/tests/CMakeLists.txt#L73) in the top-level directory with all the necessary variables filled in.

You also need `pytest-xdist` for the `numprocesses` option.

comment.body: I did some debugging with @vsoftco, and it turns out on his machine GCC and Clang report different sets of supported CPU extensions. We should address that in the coming days.

issue.body:
## Build Instructions

To build on UNIX-y systems: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -GNinja .. && ninja`

To build on Windows: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -G "Ninja" .. && ninja"` in the VS Developer console. Alternatively, just running `cmake ..` will generate build files for Visual Studio.

To use (or not use) OpenSSL, pass `-DUSE_OPENSSL={ON|OFF}`

comment.body:
> Some of the tests fail on my CPU due to CPU instruction detection, we should fix this in the future. Debug is OK. On my Debian, it seems I have to upgrade to OpenSSL 1.1.1 (my version was 1.1.0 and SHA3* functions that failed on linking were not there). I'd say let's move along with this and merge it, then keep fixing it.

@vsoftco I just pushed aab0dfb which uses CMake to check that you've got OpenSSL ≥ 1.1.1.  So that should stop CMake on Debian Stretch at the CMake phase, rather than the compilation phase.

issue.title: Mingw-w64 support
issue.body: Builds successfully on Arch Linux and passes tests in Wine

issue.title: Allow Linux and MacOs to consume this wrapper without issues
issue.body:
This pull request contains codes that allow Linux and macOS to consume this wrapper.

The changes are: (Updated)

1. ~~Addition of Lib_OQS_KEM_* and Lib_OQS_SIG_* methods for both Linux and macOS. (They are essentially pointed to the original signature in DllImport)~~
[Update] I have found out that DllImport actually prepend "lib" into library names for linux and macOS. However, they have to be exact as in "liboqs.so" is not equals to "liboqs.so.0.0.0" As a result, the changes would just be [DllImport("oqs")] instead. (If you want to support the versioning, AssemblyLoadContext would be needed)

2. Changed target frameworks to netstandard1.2 and netstandard2.0 allowing different version of .Net Core and .Net framework version to use this library. (netstandard1.2 is added for compatibility with the existing test case for netcoreapp1.1)

3. Removed prebuild event for all projects except test case to allow other OS to execute the new dotnet cli commands.

4. Addition of some useful scripts that can be used for reference for building this project. (Consist of Windows, Linux and macOS variants)

5. Updated documentation in README.md to have a slightly more verbose information on how to build the sample application and the wrapper.

Sample Application Tested on:
- [x] Windows 10
- [x] Linux (Ubuntu 18.04 LTS)
- [x] macOS (Mojave)

Relevant issues: #2 #10

comment.body: Thanks for the updates @jianmingyong. I've just pushed an update to the README. I'll give it another test on Windows...
